channel.title: The chicken or the egg?
channel.description: Which one was first?The chicken or the egg?Or maybe the rooster?Discuss here.

item.title: The chicken or the egg?
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

exe626:

legit, I don’t see what your proving. Didn’t he say “can’t”?

If two animals are classified as a species by being able to interbreed, then two animals not classified as one species cannot interbreed.

Quote:

In general, for large, complex, organisms that reproduce sexually (such as mammals and birds), one of several variations on the isolation or biological species concept is employed. Often, the distinction between different species, even quite closely related ones, is simple. Horses (Equus caballus) and donkeys (Equus asinus) are easily told apart even without study or training, and yet are so closely related that they can interbreed after a fashion. Because the result, a mule or hinny, is not usually fertile, they are clearly separate species.

Read full topic

item.title: The chicken or the egg?
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“MybJames, post:64, topic:99158”]http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/species

Tell me where it says that the definition of species is that specie in question can’t have fertile babies with another group of species.[/quote]

spe·cies (spē’shēz, -sēz) Pronunciation Key
n. pl. species

  1. Biology
    1. A fundamental category of taxonomic classification, ranking below a genus or subgenus and consisting of related organisms capable of interbreeding. See Table at taxonomy.

Read full topic

item.title: The chicken or the egg?
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

The chicken came first.
Or if you want to go by the fallacy of evolution, I’d say the egg came first.
Supposedly, two avian species would have mated, and at some stage (probably during recombination in meiosis), the DNA mutated - creating our great & tasty chicken.
I know the argument has passed that stage already, but I am in a procrastinating-from-biology-homework mood

Read full topic

item.title: The chicken or the egg?
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.description:
@Bang_Train wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:56, topic:99158”][quote author=Zach1188 link=topic=142416.msg1660003#msg1660003 date=1186562432]
Honestly, common sense.

If a blue and gold can successfully mate with a scarlet macaw, a catalina should be able to mate with another catalina provided the hybrids are not sterile.

Edit:
But, I will try to find proof because of my own curiosity.
[/quote]

It’s not common sense. A donkey can mate with a horse to form a mule, though a mule cannot reproduce with another mule.[/quote]

they actually can sort of.
its a 1 in a million genetic chance

Several female mules have produced offspring when mated with a purebred horse or ass. Since 1527 there have been more than 60 documented cases of foals born to female mules around the world. Mules and hinnies have 63 chromosomes that are a mixture of one from each parent. The different structure and number usually prevents the chromosomes from pairing up properly and creating successful embryos.

Though I dont think 2 mules can mate.

Read full topic

item.title: The chicken or the egg?
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“Zach1188, post:57, topic:99158”]Good point.

I came across this: http://animal-world.com/encyclo/birds/macaws/catalina.php
It says since it’s a hybrid they are “generally” not bred. That implies its possible, but I don’t know.

Edit:
http://animal-world.com/encyclo/birds/macaws/HarlequinXShamrock.php
This is a hybrid between two different hybrids, it also implies two hybrids of the same species can mate.[/quote]

A hybrid between two different hybrids doesn’t count, because it doesn’t create either of the parent species. Such hybrids are not species therefore and because it cannot have fertile offspring. There is no species name for the catalina macaw, no matter how hard you look.

Read full topic

Honestly, common sense.

If a blue and gold can successfully mate with a scarlet macaw, a catalina should be able to mate with another catalina provided the hybrids are not sterile.

Edit:
But, I will try to find proof because of my own curiosity.
[/quote]

It’s not common sense. A donkey can mate with a horse to form a mule, though a mule cannot reproduce with another mule.[/quote]
Good point.

I came across this: http://animal-world.com/encyclo/birds/macaws/catalina.php
It says since it’s a hybrid they are “generally” not bred. That implies its possible, but I don’t know.

Edit:
http://animal-world.com/encyclo/birds/macaws/HarlequinXShamrock.php
This is a hybrid between two different hybrids, it also implies two hybrids of the same species can mate.

item.title: The chicken or the egg?
item.dc:creator: @Zach1188 Zach1188
item.description:
@Zach1188 wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:54, topic:99158”][quote author=Zach1188 link=topic=142416.msg1659656#msg1659656 date=1186549721]
Heres an example, this one I KNOW to be true; a blue and gold macaw and a scarlet macaw (two species of macaw (parrots) which are quite different) can reproduce.
[/quote]

Can a catalina macaw make babies with another catalina macaw? If so, cite your source.[/quote]
Honestly, common sense.

If a blue and gold can successfully mate with a scarlet macaw, a catalina should be able to mate with another catalina provided the hybrids are not sterile.

Edit:
But, I will try to find proof because of my own curiosity.

Read full topic
